related.description: American students are bored by math, science and engineering. They buy smartphones and tablets by the millions but don't pursue the skills necessary to build them. Engineers and physicists are often portrayed as clueless geeks on television, and despite the high pay and the importance of such jobs to the country's future, the vast majority of high school graduates don't want to go after them.
related.title: Who Says Math Has to Be Boring?

related.description: A number of education trends made their mark in 2013, from massive open online courses to evaluating colleges based on their graduation rates. The underlying forces that drove change this year aren't likely to change anytime soon: declining public funding, changing demographics, advancing technology, and a tough job market.

title: Tricky Activists Protest The Corporatization Of Education With A Brilliant Fake Site
content:
After the prestigious New York art-school Cooper Union decided last month to charge its students tuition for the first time in 111 years, students have taken to Occupy-style tactics to protest the change, taking over the president's office for a full week.

And while the issue is quite serious--students wept at the news that the soul of their school is in jeopardy--a new piece of media activism takes a tone that's wryly comical.

"Welcome to the NEW Cooper Union," reads the headline of the faux website CooperUnion.Biz, which comes up in Google results when you search for the school's name and presents a sardonic vision of the institution's future as it adopts a more economic mindset.

For more great activist Pranks, check out the Yes Men's last great showing, Coal Cares, a site where coal companies gave away cartoon-branded inhalers for kids.

Changes at the school include such innovations as the "Home Depot School of Architecture," Donald Trump as chairman of the board of trustees, and money-making satellite campuses in Beijing and Dubai. Campus events include an art auction in the school's great hall, while Fast and the Furious plays in its screening rooms. Applying is as simple as entering credit card details. It's the corporatization of academia at its most extreme, with the accompanying dilution of the quality of an education, values, and standards.

This isn't the first time student activists have used fake websites to decry Cooper Union's dire economic situation. Last year, a student graphic designer created a successful media hoax when his fake website and press release announcing that Cooper Union would rent out its new $177 million dollar academic building to NYU got picked up by blogs. The glamorous building is viewed by many as an icon of the school's economic mismanagement, of which future students will be forced to bare the brunt.
